Œ†j={‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œû¬Øj)‚Äã(1Sj‚ÄãŒ®j,œÑglobal+1Œ®j,œÑglobal),if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|>1,‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œûm)‚Äã(1sm‚ÄãŒ®max,œÑlocal+1Œ®max,œÑlocal),if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|=1.subscriptŒ†ùëócases‚Ñ∞subscript¬ØŒûùëó1subscriptùëÜùëósuperscriptsubscriptŒ®ùëóùúèglobal1superscriptsubscriptŒ®ùëóùúèglobalifsubscriptùëó1‚Ñ∞subscriptŒûùëö1subscriptùë†ùëösuperscriptsubscriptŒ®ùúèlocal1superscriptsubscriptŒ®ùúèlocalifsubscriptùëó1\displaystyle\Pi_{j}\!=\!\begin{cases}\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{S_{j}\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}}\Big{)},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ \mathcal{E}(\Xi_{m})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{s_{m}\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}\Big{)},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1.\end{cases} (25)

6) Federation satisfaction function. The federation satisfaction function ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)ùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëó\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j}) measures the satisfaction that the pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j} receives in the expected accuracy loss Œ†jsubscriptŒ†ùëó\Pi_{j}. Generally, the lower the accuracy loss, the higher the federation satisfaction. Besides, it becomes harder to further reduce the accuracy loss when the loss is smaller, indicating that the faster the drop rate of accuracy loss, the higher the obtained federation satisfaction. Thereby, ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)ùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëó\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j}) should satisfy ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)‚â•0ùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëó0\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})\geq 0, d‚ÄãùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)d‚ÄãŒ†j<0dùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëódsubscriptŒ†ùëó0\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})}{\mathrm{d}\Pi_{j}}<0, and d2‚ÄãùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)d‚ÄãŒ†j2‚â•0superscriptd2ùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëódsuperscriptsubscriptŒ†ùëó20\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})}{\mathrm{d}\Pi_{j}^{2}}\geq 0. A well-suited satisfaction function satisfying these requirements can be the exponential decay function [35] given by

ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)=Œ≥s‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥d‚ãÖŒ†j),ùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëósubscriptùõæùë†‚ãÖsubscriptùõæùëësubscriptŒ†ùëó\displaystyle\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})=\gamma_{s}\exp(-\gamma_{d}\cdot\Pi_{j}), (26)

where Œ≥s>0subscriptùõæùë†0\gamma_{s}>0 is the satisfaction parameter, and Œ≥d>0subscriptùõæùëë0\gamma_{d}>0 is the decay parameter which controls the decay speed. A larger Œ≥dsubscriptùõæùëë\gamma_{d} indicates a faster decay of satisfaction.

Next, we analyze the federation cost in pool formulation.

7) Federation cost function. The miners in pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j} need to frequently synchronize the latest global model from the curator. According to [36, 37], the federation cost ùíû‚Äã(‚Ñëj)ùíûsubscriptùëó\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j}) can be measured by the communication cost which varies linearly with the federation size |‚Ñëj|subscriptùëó{|\Im_{j}|}. We have

ùíû‚Äã(‚Ñëj)={Œªc‚Äã|‚Ñëj|,if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|>1,0,if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|=1,ùíûsubscriptùëócasessubscriptùúÜùëêsubscriptùëóifsubscriptùëó10ifsubscriptùëó1\displaystyle\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j})=\begin{cases}\lambda_{c}{|\Im_{j}|},&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ 0,&\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1,\end{cases} (27)

where Œªc>0subscriptùúÜùëê0\lambda_{c}>0 is a scaling factor.

Finally, the federation utility of pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j} can be obtained as the difference between the federation satisfaction and the federation cost, i.e.,

ùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñëj)=ùíÆ‚Äã(Œ†j)‚àíùíû‚Äã(‚Ñëj)ùí∞subscriptùëóùíÆsubscriptŒ†ùëóùíûsubscriptùëó\displaystyle~{}~{}\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j})=\mathcal{S}(\Pi_{j})-\mathcal{C}(\Im_{j})
={Œ≥s‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥d‚Äã‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œû¬Øj)‚Äã(1‚àëm=1|‚Ñëj|Œ±m‚Äãsm‚Äã‚åäTœÑtrainDjmax‚åã+‚åäTœÑtrainDjmax‚åã‚àí1))‚àíŒªc‚Äã|‚Ñëj|,if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|>1,Œ≥s‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àíŒ≥d‚Äã‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œûj)‚Äã(1sj‚ÄãŒ®max,œÑlocal+1Œ®max,œÑlocal)),if‚Äã|‚Ñëj|=1.absentcasessubscriptùõæùë†subscriptùõæùëë‚Ñ∞subscript¬ØŒûùëó1superscriptsubscriptùëö1subscriptùëósubscriptùõºùëösubscriptùë†ùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëáùúètrainsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëósuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùúètrainsuperscriptsubscriptùê∑ùëó1otherwisesubscriptùúÜùëêsubscriptùëóifsubscriptùëó1otherwisesubscriptùõæùë†subscriptùõæùëë‚Ñ∞subscriptŒûùëó1subscriptùë†ùëósuperscriptsubscriptŒ®ùúèlocal1superscriptsubscriptŒ®ùúèlocalifsubscriptùëó1otherwise\displaystyle\!=\!\begin{cases}\gamma_{s}\exp\left(-\gamma_{d}\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{\sum_{m=1}^{|\Im_{j}|}{\alpha_{m}s_{m}}\big{\lfloor}\frac{T_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}}}{D_{j}^{\max}}\big{\rfloor}}}\!+\!{\Big{\lfloor}\frac{T_{\tau}^{\mathrm{train}}}{D_{j}^{\max}}\Big{\rfloor}}^{\!-\!1}\Big{)}\right)\\ ~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}-\lambda_{c}{|\Im_{j}|},~{}\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}>1,\\ \gamma_{s}\exp\left(-\gamma_{d}\mathcal{E}(\Xi_{j})\Big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{s_{j}\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}}+\frac{1}{\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}}}\Big{)}\right),\mathrm{if}\ {|\Im_{j}|}=1.\end{cases} (28)

Let W‚Äã(‚Ñë)ùëäW(\Im) denote the social welfare of a partition ‚Ñë\Im, i.e., the sum of federation utilities of disjoint pools in a partition ‚Ñë\Im. The target of PF-PoFL is to maximize the social welfare by forming the optimal partition structure ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript\Im^{*}, where the optimization problem for task œÑùúè\tau is formulated as:

ùêèùê´ùê®ùêõùê•ùêûùê¶:max‚Å°W‚Äã(‚Ñë):=‚àëj=1|‚Ñë|ùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñëj).:ùêèùê´ùê®ùêõùê•ùêûùê¶assignùëäsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùí∞subscriptùëó\displaystyle\mathbf{Problem:}\,\max W(\Im):=\sum\nolimits_{j=1}^{|\Im|}{\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j})}.
s.t.‚Ñëj‚à©‚Ñëj‚Ä≤=‚àÖ,‚àÄj‚â†j‚Ä≤,‚à™j=1|‚Ñë|‚Ñëj=‚Ñ≥œÑ.formulae-sequencestformulae-sequencesubscriptùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤formulae-sequencefor-allùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëósubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\displaystyle\mathrm{s.t.}\ {\Im_{j}}\cap{\Im_{j^{\prime}}}=\emptyset,\forall j\neq j^{\prime},\cup_{j=1}^{{|\Im|}}{\Im_{j}}=\mathcal{M}_{\tau}. (29)

V-B Stable Pool Formation Algorithm

To solve the problem in (V-A), the pooled-mining formation process among miners is modeled as a federation formation game with transferable utility (FFG-TU), where distributed miners (as game players) tend to form various disjoint federations to maximize their individual profits [38].

Definition 2 (FFG-TU game): For each uncompleted FL task œÑùúè\tau, a FFG-TU game for optimized pool structure is defined by a triple (‚Ñ≥œÑ,ùí∞,‚Ñë)subscript‚Ñ≥ùúèùí∞(\mathcal{M}_{\tau},\mathcal{U},\Im), where the specific formulation is shown as below.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Players: The players of the game is the set of miners (i.e., ‚Ñ≥œÑsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{M}_{\tau}) that participate FL task œÑùúè\tau.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Transferable federation utility: ùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñëj)ùí∞subscriptùëó\mathcal{U}(\Im_{j}) is the federation utility of each federation (or pool) ‚Ñëj‚äÜ‚Ñ≥œÑsubscriptùëósubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\Im_{j}\subseteq\mathcal{M}_{\tau}, which can be apportioned arbitrarily among the members of ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Pooled structure: A pooled structure (or a federation partition) is defined as the set ‚Ñë={‚Ñë1,‚ãØ,‚ÑëJ}subscript1‚ãØsubscriptùêΩ\Im=\{\Im_{1},\cdots,\Im_{J}\} that partitions the miner set ‚Ñ≥œÑsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{M}_{\tau}. Here, ‚Ñëj,j=1,‚ãØ,Jformulae-sequencesubscriptùëóùëó1‚ãØùêΩ\Im_{j},j=1,\cdots,J are disjoint federations such that ‚Ñëj‚à©‚Ñëj‚Ä≤=‚àÖsubscriptùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤{\Im_{j}}\cap{\Im_{j^{\prime}}}=\emptyset, ‚àÄj‚â†j‚Ä≤for-allùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤\forall j\neq j^{\prime}, and ‚à™j=1J‚Ñëj=‚Ñ≥œÑsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùêΩsubscriptùëósubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\cup_{j=1}^{J}{\Im_{j}}=\mathcal{M}_{\tau}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Strategy: Each miner decides whether to work alone by adopting the solo mining strategy or choose a federation to join to cooperatively train a FL model using the federated mining strategy.

Definition 3 (Switch operation): A switch operation Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m) is defined as the transfer of miner mùëöm from the current pool ‚Ñël‚àà‚Ñësubscriptùëô\Im_{l}\in\Im to another pool ‚Ñëk‚àà‚Ñë‚à™{‚àÖ}subscriptùëò\Im_{k}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}, mathematically,

Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m):‚Ñël‚ñ∑{‚Ñël‚àí,{m}}‚Äãand‚Äã{‚Ñëk,{m}}‚ñ∑‚Ñëk+.:subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö‚ñ∑subscriptùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùëôùëöandsubscriptùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}(m):\Im_{l}\triangleright\{\Im_{l}^{-},\{m\}\}\ \mathrm{and}\ \{\Im_{k},\{m\}\}\triangleright\Im_{k}^{+}. (30)
Remark 2

The switch operation consists of two successive parts: the split operation (i.e., ‚Ñël‚ñ∑{‚Ñël‚àí,{m}}‚ñ∑subscriptùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùëôùëö\Im_{l}\triangleright\{\Im_{l}^{-},\{m\}\}) and the merge operation (i.e., {‚Ñëk,{m}}‚ñ∑‚Ñëk+‚ñ∑subscriptùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëò\{\Im_{k},\{m\}\}\triangleright\Im_{k}^{+}), where ‚Ñël‚àí=‚Ñël\{m}superscriptsubscriptùëô\subscriptùëôùëö\Im_{l}^{-}=\Im_{l}\backslash\{m\} and ‚Ñël+=‚Ñëk‚à™{m}superscriptsubscriptùëôsubscriptùëòùëö\Im_{l}^{+}=\Im_{k}\cup\{m\}. In the case that ‚Ñël={m}subscriptùëôùëö\Im_{l}=\{m\}, Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m) means the merge of ‚Ñëlsubscriptùëô\Im_{l} with ‚Ñëksubscriptùëò\Im_{k}, causing the number of federations decrease by one. In the case that ‚Ñëk={‚àÖ}subscriptùëò\Im_{k}=\{\emptyset\}, Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m) means the formation of a new singleton ‚Ñëk={m}subscriptùëòùëö\Im_{k}=\{m\}, causing the number of federations increase by one. In the case that k=lùëòùëôk=l, it means miner nùëõn stays in the current federation and the number of federations remains unchanged.

Definition 4 (Switch gain): The switch gain Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k}) related to the switch operation Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m) is defined as:

Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k):=vm‚Äã(‚Ñëk‚à™{m})‚àívm‚Äã(‚Ñël)assignsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòsubscriptùë£ùëösubscriptùëòùëösubscriptùë£ùëösubscriptùëô\displaystyle\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k}):=v_{m}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\})-v_{m}(\Im_{l})
=[ùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñëk‚à™{m})‚àíùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñëk)]‚àí[ùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñël)‚àíùí∞‚Äã(‚Ñël\{m})].absentdelimited-[]ùí∞subscriptùëòùëöùí∞subscriptùëòdelimited-[]ùí∞subscriptùëôùí∞\subscriptùëôùëö\displaystyle=[\mathcal{U}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\})-\mathcal{U}(\Im_{k})]-[\mathcal{U}(\Im_{l})-\mathcal{U}(\Im_{l}\backslash\{m\})]. (31)

Here, vm‚Äã(‚Ñëk‚à™{m})subscriptùë£ùëösubscriptùëòùëöv_{m}(\Im_{k}\cup\{m\}) and vm‚Äã(‚Ñël)subscriptùë£ùëösubscriptùëôv_{m}(\Im_{l}) mean the extra utility value that miner mùëöm brings to the pools ‚Ñëk‚à™{m}subscriptùëòùëö\Im_{k}\cup\{m\} and ‚Ñëlsubscriptùëô\Im_{l}, respectively.

Remark 3

Specially, we define Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)=0subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò0\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})=0 when k=lùëòùëôk=l. Besides, when ‚Ñëk={‚àÖ}subscriptùëò\Im_{k}=\{\emptyset\}, we have Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,‚àÖ)=ùí∞‚Äã({m})‚àívm‚Äã(‚Ñël)subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùí∞ùëösubscriptùë£ùëösubscriptùëô\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,\emptyset})=\mathcal{U}(\{m\})-v_{m}(\Im_{l}). The transferable switch gain in the pool switch operation accords with the transferable utility of our proposed federation formation game. Besides, the federation gain of any switch operation only relies on the utilities of involved pools, rather than the manner that federation utilities are shared among their members.

Definition 5 (Preference order): For any miner m‚àà‚Ñ≥œÑùëösubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèm\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau}, the preference order ‚™∞succeeds-or-equals\succeq is defined as a complete and transitive binary relation between two switch operations Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m) and Œ¶l‚Ä≤,k‚Ä≤‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶superscriptùëô‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùëö\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m) such that:

Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)‚™∞Œ¶l‚Ä≤,k‚Ä≤‚Äã(m)‚áîŒ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)‚â•Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l‚Ä≤,k‚Ä≤).‚áîsucceeds-or-equalssubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëösubscriptŒ¶superscriptùëô‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶superscriptùëô‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}(m)\succeq\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m)\Leftrightarrow\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})\geq\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}). (32)

Similarly, for the strict preference order ‚âªsucceeds\succ, we also have Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)‚âªŒ¶l‚Ä≤,k‚Ä≤‚Äã(m)‚áîŒ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)>Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l‚Ä≤,k‚Ä≤)‚áîsucceedssubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëösubscriptŒ¶superscriptùëô‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶superscriptùëô‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤\Phi_{l,k}(m)\succ\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}(m)\Leftrightarrow\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l^{\prime},k^{\prime}}).

As miners can transfer from one federation to another, the federation partition (i.e., ‚Ñë{\Im}) varies with time. The solution of the proposed FFG-TU game is a stable pooled structure ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript\Im^{*}. In general, the stable partition outcome can be attained using exhaustive search methods, where the possible partition iterations increase exponentially with the number of involved miners [37]. In the following, we design a distributed stable pool formation algorithm with low computational complexity in Algorithm¬†3 to obtain the optimal federation partition strategy of each player (i.e., miner mùëöm) in the game. The proposed algorithm consists of the following three phases.

Phase 1: Pool initialization (line 3). At the beginning (h=0‚Ñé0h=0), an initial partition ‚Ñë(0)superscript0{\Im^{(0)}} is generated according to the specific application. For example, the initial partition can be the result of the stable partition outcome for the previously finished FL task.

Phase 2: Switch strategy-making on miner's side¬†(lines 5‚Äì8). Given the current federation partition ‚Ñë(h)={‚Ñë1(h),‚ãØ,‚ÑëJ(h)(h)}superscript‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript1‚Ñé‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùêΩ‚Ñé‚Ñé{\Im}^{(h)}=\{\Im_{1}^{(h)},\cdots,\Im_{J^{(h)}}^{(h)}\}, each miner can opt three strategies: (i) stay in the current federation; (ii) split from the current federation and merge with any other non-empty federation; and (iii) split from the current federation and act alone. The first two strategies are federated mining strategies and the last one is the solo mining strategy. To formulate each miner's switch strategy, the switchable candidate pool is first defined as below.

Definition 6 (Switchable candidate pool): For each miner m‚àà‚Ñëlùëösubscriptùëôm\in{\Im_{l}}, its switchable candidate pool set is defined as ùíûmpoolsuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}, where Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)>0,‚àÄ‚Ñëk‚ààùíûmpool‚äÜ‚Ñë‚à™{‚àÖ}formulae-sequencesubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò0for-allsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>0,\forall\Im_{k}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\subseteq\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}. In other words, only the pool with positive switch gain can be added into the switchable candidate pool set.

Remark 4

If Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)‚â§0,‚àÄ‚Ñëk‚àà‚Ñë‚à™{‚àÖ}formulae-sequencesubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò0for-allsubscriptùëò\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})\leq 0,\forall\Im_{k}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\}, there exists no available federation in ‚Ñë\Im nor the empty set to transfer for the miner mùëöm (i.e., ùíûmpool=‚àÖsuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}=\emptyset), indicating that the miner intends to stay in the current federation ‚Ñëlsubscriptùëô\Im_{l} (i.e., Œ¶l,l‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëôùëö\Phi_{l,l}(m)). Otherwise, the miner makes its strategy based on the following switch rule.

Definition 7 (Switch rule): Given the switchable candidate pool set ùíûmpool‚à™{‚àÖ}superscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, each miner m‚àà‚Ñëlùëösubscriptùëôm\in{\Im_{l}} sends transfer request to the candidate pool ‚Ñëj‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëó\Im_{j^{*}} with the largest switch gain, i.e.,

‚Ñëj‚àó=arg‚Äãmax‚Å°Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j),m‚àà‚Ñël,‚àÄ‚Ñëj‚ààùíûmpool‚à™{‚àÖ},formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëóargmaxsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëóformulae-sequenceùëösubscriptùëôfor-allsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\displaystyle\Im_{j^{*}}=\operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j}),m\in{\Im_{l}},\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, (35)

where ‚Ñëlsubscriptùëô{\Im_{l}} is the current federation of miner mùëöm.

Remark 5

In the case arg‚Äãmax‚Å°{Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j):‚àÄ‚Ñëj‚ààùíûmpool‚à™{‚àÖ}}={‚àÖ}argmax:subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëófor-allsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\operatorname{arg\,max}\big{\{}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!:\!\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}\big{\}}\!=\!\{\emptyset\}, it means that the miner mùëöm prefers the solo mining strategy and will split from the current federation (i.e., Œ¶l,‚àÖ‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëö\Phi_{l,\emptyset}(m)). In the other case arg‚Äãmax‚Å°{Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j):‚àÄ‚Ñëj‚ààùíûmpool‚à™{‚àÖ}}=‚Ñëj‚àóargmax:subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëófor-allsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpoolsubscriptsuperscriptùëó\operatorname{arg\,max}\left\{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!:\!\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}\right\}=\Im_{j^{*}}, it means that the miner mùëöm prefers splitting from the current federation ‚Ñëlsubscriptùëô\Im_{l} and merging with another federation ‚Ñëj‚àósubscriptsuperscriptùëó\Im_{j^{*}} (i.e., Œ¶l,j‚àó‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôsuperscriptùëóùëö\Phi_{l,j^{*}}(m)).

To summarize, ‚àÄ‚Ñëj‚ààùíûmpool‚à™{‚àÖ}for-allsubscriptùëósuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpool\forall\Im_{j}\in\mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}\cup\{\emptyset\}, the optimal switch strategy of each miner m‚àà‚Ñëlùëösubscriptùëôm\in\Im_{l} can be expressed as

Œ¶l,k‚àó‚Äã(m)={Œ¶l,l‚Äã(m),if‚Äãùíûmpool=‚àÖ,Œ¶l,‚àÖ‚Äã(m),if‚Äãarg‚Äãmax‚Å°Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j)={‚àÖ},Œ¶l,j‚àó‚Äã(m),if‚Äãarg‚Äãmax‚Å°Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j)=‚Ñëj‚àó.superscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëöcasessubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëôùëöifsuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëöpoolsubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëöifargmaxsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëósubscriptŒ¶ùëôsuperscriptùëóùëöifargmaxsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëó\displaystyle\Phi_{l,k}^{*}(m)=\begin{cases}\Phi_{l,l}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \mathcal{C}_{m}^{\mathrm{pool}}=\emptyset,\\ \Phi_{l,\emptyset}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!=\!\{\emptyset\},\\ \Phi_{l,j^{*}}(m),&\mathrm{if}\ \operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j})\!=\!\Im_{j^{*}}.\end{cases} (36)

Phase 3: Admission strategy-making on pool's side (lines 9‚Äì17). When multiple miners request to join the same pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j}, the switch order can affect the federation utilities and the federation formation outcome. To capture the pool's preference for the transfer order, the admission rule is defined as below.

Definition 8 (Admission rule): For a set of candidate miners (i.e., ùíûjminersuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëóminer\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}) that send transfer request to the same pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j}, only the candidate m‚àósuperscriptùëöm^{*} with the largest switch gain is permitted by the pool ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j}, i.e.,

m‚àó=arg‚Äãmax‚Å°Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,j),m‚àà‚Ñël,‚àÄm‚ààùíûjminer,formulae-sequencesuperscriptùëöargmaxsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëóformulae-sequenceùëösubscriptùëôfor-allùëösuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëóminer\displaystyle{m^{*}}=\operatorname{arg\,max}\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,j}),m\in{\Im_{l}},\forall m\in\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}, (37)

and other candidate miners in the set ùíûjminer\{m‚àó}\superscriptsubscriptùíûùëóminersuperscriptùëö\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\backslash\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\} are rejected.

According to the admission rule, each pool ‚Ñëj‚àà‚Ñësubscriptùëó\Im_{j}\in\Im accepts the most preferred miner m‚àó‚àà‚Ñël‚Ä≤superscriptùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤m^{*}\in\Im_{l^{\prime}} (in line 11) and rejects other candidates (in line 12). Correspondingly, the switch operation is performed between two pools ‚Ñëj,‚Ñël‚Ä≤‚àà‚Ñësubscriptùëósubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤\Im_{j},\Im_{l^{\prime}}\in\Im consisting of the split operation (i.e., ‚Ñël‚Ä≤(h)‚ñ∑{‚Ñël‚Ä≤(h+1),{m‚àó}}‚ñ∑superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤‚Ñésuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤‚Ñé1superscriptùëö{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h)}}\triangleright\big{\{}{{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h+1)}},\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}}\big{\}}) and the merge operation (i.e., {‚Ñëj(h),{m‚àó}}‚ñ∑‚Ñëj(h+1)‚ñ∑superscriptsubscriptùëó‚Ñésuperscriptùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëó‚Ñé1\big{\{}{{\Im_{j}^{(h)}},\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}}\big{\}}\triangleright{\Im_{j}^{(h+1)}}), where ‚Ñël‚Ä≤(h+1)=‚Ñël‚Ä≤(h)\{m‚àó}superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤‚Ñé1\superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùëô‚Ä≤‚Ñésuperscriptùëö{\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h+1)}}={\Im_{l^{\prime}}^{(h)}}\backslash\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\} and ‚Ñëj(h+1)=‚Ñëj(h)‚à™{m‚àó}superscriptsubscriptùëó‚Ñé1superscriptsubscriptùëó‚Ñésuperscriptùëö{\Im_{j}^{(h+1)}}={\Im_{j}^{(h)}}\cup\left\{{{m^{*}}}\right\}. Then, the federation structure is updated as ‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚Ñë(h+1)‚Üísuperscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1{\Im}^{(h)}\rightarrow{\Im}^{(h+1)} (in line 17).

The above phases 2-3 are repeated until no miner m‚àà‚Ñël‚àó‚äÜ‚Ñ≥œÑùëösuperscriptsubscriptùëôsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèm\in\Im_{l}^{*}\subseteq\mathcal{M}_{\tau} in the final pooled structure ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript\Im^{*} intends to execute switch operations to increase the overall gain by transferring to another pool ‚Ñëj‚àó‚àà‚Ñë‚àó‚à™{‚àÖ}superscriptsubscriptùëósuperscript\Im_{j}^{*}\in{\Im}^{*}\cup\{\emptyset\} with j‚â†lùëóùëôj\neq l, i.e., Œ¶l,l‚Äã(m)‚™∞Œ¶l,j‚Äã(m)succeeds-or-equalssubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëôùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëóùëö\Phi_{l,l}(m)\succeq\Phi_{l,j}(m).

V-C Property Analysis

Given any initial partition ‚Ñë(0)superscript0\Im^{(0)}, the federation formation procedure can be formulated as a sequence of switch operations, i.e.,

{‚Ñë(0)‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üí‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üí‚Ñë(H)=‚Ñë‚àó},‚Üísuperscript0‚ãØ‚Üísuperscript‚Ñé‚Üí‚ãØ‚Üísuperscriptùêªsuperscript\displaystyle\{{\Im^{(0)}}\to\cdots\to{\Im^{(h)}}\to\cdots\to{\Im^{(H)}}={\Im}^{*}\}, (38)

where HùêªH is total number of transformations.

Lemma 1

Any successive transformation of the federation partition, i.e., ‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚Ñë(h+1),h={0,1,‚ãØ,H‚àí1}formulae-sequence‚Üísuperscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1‚Ñé01‚ãØùêª1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}},h=\{0,1,\cdots,H-1\}, can improve the social welfare for miners in ‚Ñ≥œÑsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{M}_{\tau}.

Proof:

According to Definitions 6‚Äì7, for each switch operation Œ¶l,k‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëö\Phi_{l,k}(m), it results in a strictly positive gain Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)>0subscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò0\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})>0 for the two involved pools ‚Ñëjsubscriptùëó\Im_{j} and ‚Ñëksubscriptùëò\Im_{k}, while the utilities of other pools in ‚Ñë\{‚Ñëj,‚Ñëk}\subscriptùëósubscriptùëò\Im\backslash\{\Im_{j},\Im_{k}\} remain unchanged. Let ‚àë(h)superscript‚Ñé\sum^{(h)} be the set of permitted switch operations during the transformation ‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚Ñë(h+1)‚Üísuperscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}. Therefore, we can obtain

W‚Äã(‚Ñë(h+1))=W‚Äã(‚Ñë(h))+‚àëŒ¶l,k‚Äã(m)‚àà‚àë(h)Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k).ùëäsuperscript‚Ñé1ùëäsuperscript‚ÑésubscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëösuperscript‚ÑésubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò\displaystyle W\big{(}\Im^{(h+1)}\big{)}=W\big{(}\Im^{(h)}\big{)}+\sum_{\Phi_{l,k}(m)\in\sum^{(h)}}{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})}. (39)

The second term in the right side of (39) means the improved social welfare (i.e., the sum of added switch gains) during ‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚Ñë(h+1)‚Üísuperscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}. As ‚àëŒ¶l,k‚Äã(m)‚àà‚àë(h)Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶l,k)>0subscriptsubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëòùëösuperscript‚ÑésubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëôùëò0\sum_{\Phi_{l,k}(m)\in\sum^{(h)}}{\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{l,k})}>0, we have W‚Äã(‚Ñë(h+1))>W‚Äã(‚Ñë(h))ùëäsuperscript‚Ñé1ùëäsuperscript‚ÑéW(\Im^{(h+1)})>W(\Im^{(h)}). Lemma¬†1 is proved. ‚àé

In the following, we first prove the convergence of federation partition transformations in Theorem¬†3. Then, we prove the Nash-stability, near-optimality, and low computational complexity in Theorems¬†4, 5, 6, respectively.

Theorem 3

Given an arbitrary initial pooled structure ‚Ñë(0)superscript0\Im^{(0)}, the proposed Algorithm¬†3 can always converge to a final disjoint federation partition ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im}^{*} after a finite number of transformations.

Proof:

According to the miner's switch strategy defined in Eq. (36), we can observe that a single switch operation either yields (i) a previously visited partition with a non-cooperative miner (i.e., a singleton) or (ii) an unvisited new partition.

Case (i). When it comes to the partition structure ‚Ñë(h)superscript‚Ñé\Im^{(h)} where miner mùëöm forms a singleton, the non-cooperative miner mùëöm should either join a new federation or decide to remain non-cooperative in the next iteration ‚Ñë(h+1)superscript‚Ñé1\Im^{(h+1)}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    If miner mùëöm chooses to join a new federation, an unvisited partition without this non-cooperative miner mùëöm will be formed via the switch operation.

  • ‚Ä¢

    If miner mùëöm chooses to remain non-cooperative, any visited partition will not appear in the transformation of the current partition structure.

Case (ii). When it comes to the partition structure ‚Ñë(h)superscript‚Ñé\Im^{(h)} where a single switch operation leads to an unvisited partition in the next iteration ‚Ñë(h+1)superscript‚Ñé1\Im^{(h+1)}, the maximum number of partitions among miners in ‚Ñ≥œÑsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{M}_{\tau} can be given by the well-known Bell number function, i.e.,

b|‚Ñ≥œÑ|=‚àëm=1|‚Ñ≥œÑ|(|‚Ñ≥œÑ|‚àí1m)‚Äãbm,‚àÄm‚àà‚Ñ≥œÑ&b0=1.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëèsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùëö1subscript‚Ñ≥ùúèsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè1ùëösubscriptùëèùëöfor-allùëösubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèsubscriptùëè01\displaystyle{b_{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}}=\sum\nolimits_{m=1}^{{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}}{\left(\begin{array}[]{l}{|\mathcal{M}_{\tau}|}\!-\!1\\ ~{}~{}~{}m\end{array}\right)}{b_{m}},\forall m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau}\ \&\ {b_{0}}=1. (42)

According to Eq. (42), the number of transformations of federation partitions in formula (38) is finite. Thereby, in all cases, the transformation sequence in formula (38) will always terminate and converge to a final partition ‚Ñë‚àó=‚Ñë(H)superscriptsuperscriptùêª{\Im}^{*}={\Im^{(H)}}, which is composed of a number of disjoint federations after finite HùêªH iterations. Theorem¬†3 is proved. ‚àé

Definition 9 (Nash-stability): A federation partition ‚Ñë={‚Ñë1,‚ãØ,‚ÑëJ}subscript1‚ãØsubscriptùêΩ\Im=\{\Im_{1},\cdots,\Im_{J}\} is Nash-stable if ‚àÄm‚àà‚Ñ≥œÑ,‚àÄ‚Ñëj‚àà‚Ñë,‚àÄ‚Ñël‚àà‚Ñë‚à™{‚àÖ},Œ©m‚Äã(Œ¶j,l)‚â§0formulae-sequencefor-allùëösubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèformulae-sequencefor-allsubscriptùëóformulae-sequencefor-allsubscriptùëôsubscriptŒ©ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëóùëô0\forall m\in\mathcal{M}_{\tau},\forall\Im_{j}\in\Im,\forall\Im_{l}\in\Im\cup\{\emptyset\},\Omega_{m}(\Phi_{j,l})\leq 0.

Remark 6

The Nash-stability implies that, under the Nash-stable partition, any single switch operation will not result in a strictly positive gain. In other words, no miner has incentives to move from its current federation to another one or to deviate and act alone in the Nash-stable partition.

Theorem 4

The final partition ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im}^{*} from Algorithm¬†3 is Nash-stable.

Proof:

The Nash-stability of partition ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im^{*}} is proved by contradiction. Suppose that the final partition ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im^{*}} resulting from Algorithm¬†3 is not Nash-stable. As a consequence, there exist a miner m‚àà‚Ñëjùëösubscriptùëóm\in\Im_{j} and a federation ‚Ñëj‚Ä≤‚àà‚Ñë‚àó‚à™{‚àÖ},j‚â†j‚Ä≤formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤superscriptùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤\Im_{j^{\prime}}\in{\Im^{*}}\cup\{\emptyset\},j\neq j^{\prime} such that Œ¶j,j‚Ä≤‚Äã(m)‚™∞Œ¶j,j‚Äã(m)succeeds-or-equalssubscriptŒ¶ùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptŒ¶ùëóùëóùëö\Phi_{j,j^{\prime}}(m){\succeq}\Phi_{j,j}(m). Under this circumstance, miner mùëöm will execute the switch operation Œ¶j,j‚Ä≤‚Äã(m)subscriptŒ¶ùëósuperscriptùëó‚Ä≤ùëö\Phi_{j,j^{\prime}}(m), which contradicts with the fact that ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im^{*}} is the final partition result of Algorithm¬†3. Theorem¬†4 is proved. ‚àé

Theorem 5

The final partition outcome from Algorithm¬†3 attains a near-optimal performance.

Proof:

According to Lemma¬†1, the consecutive transformation of the federation partition, i.e., ‚Ñë(h)‚Üí‚Ñë(h+1)‚Üísuperscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1{\Im^{(h)}}\to{\Im^{(h+1)}}, can improve the overall social welfare. Moreover, according to Theorem¬†3, the overall system welfare derived by Algorithm¬†3 is convergent after several iterations. Besides, instead of allowing multiple miners to simultaneously transfer to a single pool, the switch operation to a single pool is executed in a greedy manner in our work, where only the miner with the largest positive switch gain is permitted. Thereby, the partition result derived through Algorithm¬†3 is near-optimal, which is also evaluated using simulations in comparison with the exhaustive optimal solution in Sect.¬†VI-C. ‚àé

Theorem 6

The computational complexity of the proposed Algorithm¬†3 is ùí™‚Äã(H‚ãÖJ‚ãÖ|‚Ñ≥œÑ|)ùí™‚ãÖùêªùêΩsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{O}(H\cdot J\cdot{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}), where J=|‚Ñë‚àó|ùêΩsuperscriptJ=\left|{\Im}^{*}\right| is the number of federations in the Nash-stable partition ‚Ñë‚àósuperscript{\Im}^{*}.

Proof:

The complexity of the distributed pool formation algorithm in Algorithm¬†3 mainly consists of two parts: (i) the first for-loop for each miner to decide its switch strategy (lines 5-8); and (ii) the second for-loop for each federation to decide its admission strategy (lines 9-15). For the first part, it has a complexity of ùí™‚Äã(H‚Äã|‚Ñ≥œÑ|‚ÄãJ)ùí™ùêªsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúèùêΩ\mathcal{O}(H{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}J). The second part has a complexity of ùí™‚Äã(H‚ÄãJ‚Äã|ùíûjminer|)ùí™ùêªùêΩsuperscriptsubscriptùíûùëóminer\mathcal{O}(HJ{\left|\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\right|}). As max‚Å°{|ùíûjminer|}‚â§|‚Ñ≥œÑ|superscriptsubscriptùíûùëóminersubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\max\{\left|\mathcal{C}_{j}^{\mathrm{miner}}\right|\}\leq{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}, the overall computational complexity yields ùí™‚Äã(H‚ÄãJ‚Äã|‚Ñ≥œÑ|)ùí™ùêªùêΩsubscript‚Ñ≥ùúè\mathcal{O}(HJ{\left|{{\mathcal{M}_{\tau}}}\right|}). Theorem¬†6 is proved. ‚àé

VI Performance Evaluation

In this section, the simulation setup is first introduced in Sect.¬†VI-A, followed by the numerical results and discussions in Sects.¬†VI-B‚àºsimilar-to\simVI-D.

VI-A Simulation Setup

We implement the prototype of PF-PoFL on a private blockchain network based on the open-source Go-Algorand project [39] under both local and distributed settings. For the distributed setting (i.e., setting 1), the prototype is deployed across 20 Azure B8ms virtual machines (VMs), with 8 CPU cores and 32 GB of RAM. The VMs spread across five locations: West US, Canada East, UK South, Korea South, and North Europe. Each VM hosts 5 blockchain miners, and the total number of blockchain miners (i.e., NùëÅN) is 100. For the local setting (i.e., setting 2), the prototype is deployed and tested on a single computer with Intel Core i7-8700 CPU (3.6GHz) and 32GB RAM, where the number of blockchain miners is set as 100.

We use Go 1.17 to create and manage the private multi-node networks, as well as handle all networking and distributed systems aspects. We use the Turing-complete PyTeal [40] to write the smart contract in Python 3.10 and use the¬†compileProgram¬†method to produce the bytecode-based TEAL source code, which can be deployed on the blockchain. Besides, miners in a pool use PyTorch to perform federated mining with UDP to produce SGD updates during training, and our prototype can support any AI model which can be optimized via SGD.

Dataset. We consider two types of FL tasks trained on two typical datasets: one type is the handwritten digits recognition tasks on the MNIST dataset [41]; and another is the image recognition tasks on the CIFAR-10 dataset [42]. MNIST consists of 60,000 training images and 10,000 test images with size of 28√ó28282828\times 28 in 10 classes. CIFAR-10 contains 60,000 32√ó32323232\times 32 images evenly divided in 10 classes, with 50,000 training images and 10,000 test samples. For the dataset partition among miners, the non-IID setting is adopted. Specifically, each miner is assigned with zùëßz classes of 600 training samples for MNIST (resp. 500 training samples for CIFAR-10) and the training samples of different miners can be repeated, where the integer zùëßz is randomly selected from {1,2,‚ãØ,10}12‚ãØ10\{1,2,\cdots,10\}.

Model. For federated mining within each pool in PF-PoFL, the 3-layer CNN model is adopted for MNIST, while the ResNet18 model is employed for CIFAR-10. The total number of communication rounds is set as Œ®j,œÑglobal=200superscriptsubscriptŒ®ùëóùúèglobal200\Psi_{j,\tau}^{\mathrm{global}}=200, and the sample ratio is set as Œªs=0.35subscriptùúÜùë†0.35\lambda_{s}=0.35. For the learning algorithm, the mini-batch SGD with local batch size equal to 50 is adopted for all miners, where the initial learning rate Œ∑ùúÇ\eta is set as 0.01 and declines to 0.001 after 120-th communication round. Besides, the local epoch of miners is set as 1 under the federated mining strategy, while the maximum local epoch Œ®max,œÑlocalsuperscriptsubscriptŒ®ùúèlocal\Psi_{\max,\tau}^{\mathrm{local}} of miners is set as 1000 under the solo mining strategy.

Table¬†I summarizes the datasets and models used in PF-PoFL. For the UDP model, the privacy parameters (œÉ,œµ)ùúéitalic-œµ(\sigma,\epsilon) are selected from {(3,5.52),(14,1.06),(24,0.61)}35.52141.06240.61\{(3,5.52),(14,1.06),(24,0.61)\}. Besides, we set Œ¥=1√ó10‚àí6ùõø1superscript106\delta=1\times 10^{-6}. For the federation formation game model, we set Œ≥d=30subscriptùõæùëë30\gamma_{d}=30, Œ≥s=23subscriptùõæùë†23\gamma_{s}=23, Œªc=0.01subscriptùúÜùëê0.01\lambda_{c}=0.01. In addition, we set miner's initial credit value as c‚Äãr‚Äãen0=1ùëêùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùëíùëõ01cre_{n}^{0}=1 and the credit updates as œá1=2subscriptùúí12\chi_{1}=2, œá2=4subscriptùúí24\chi_{2}=4, and œá3=1subscriptùúí31\chi_{3}=1.

Comparing method. We evaluate the performance of the PF-PoFL in comparison with the PoFL scheme [15]. In PoFL [15], its working relies on a central FL platform, and the fixed mining pool structure is employed for federated mining. PoFL ensures privacy preservation and prevents model plagiarism for trained models using homomorphic encryption (HE)-based label prediction and secure two-party computation (2PC)-based label comparison. As PoFL does not specify the detailed agreement protocol to acquire consensus, to be objective and fair, we implement the conventional Algorand BA protocol [18] for miners in PoFL to reach consensus on a new block. Here, the number of miners is set as N=100ùëÅ100N=100 and the number of malicious or Byzantine miners is set as f=20ùëì20f=20.

In the following, we first evaluate the blockchain throughput, block latency, and system overhead of our PF-PoFL in Figs.¬†7‚Äì8 and Tables¬†II‚ÄìIII. Next, we analyze the impacts of non-IID, number of miners, and privacy parameters on the federated mining process with UDP in Figs.¬†9‚Äì13. Finally, we analyze the efficiency and stability of the federation formation game approach for optimized pool structure in Figs.¬†14‚Äì15.

VI-B System Throughput and Latency

Fig.¬†7 shows the throughput (measured by transactions per second (TPS)) and the block latency (i.e., the consensus time for a block from being pending to be confirmed) of the blockchain system in the distributed setting. In the blockchain, the shorter the consensus time, the better the consensus efficiency. Here, the consensus time is mainly determined by the delay in model downloading, model ranking, model verification, block propagation, and voting-based agreement process. In the simulation, the ratio of malicious or Byzantine miners is set to be 20%. From Fig.¬†7, it can be seen that, when the block height grows from 100 to 200, both the TPS and the block latency of our proposed PF-PoFL consensus mechanism remain relatively stable. Specifically, the throughput mainly varies between [300, 500] TPS, while the block latency changes within [18, 25] seconds, which indicates a relatively stable block packaging frequency of our PF-PoFL consensus mechanism. It can be explained as follows.

In the traditional PoW consensus protocol, all miners compete to solve the same PoW puzzle and the fastest node to solve it earns the block rewards. Distinguished from the PoW protocol, in our PF-PoFL consensus protocol, different mining pools can concurrently train on different FL tasks that are in the training phase; meanwhile, in the current block height, the validators prefer to reach consensus on the most urgent and profitable task from all tasks that are in the testing phase. For example, for a FL task œÑùúè\tau with a high difficulty level, in its training phase, validators will carry out consensus on other tasks that are in the testing phase; until the FL task œÑùúè\tau reaches its testing phase, validators will perform consensus on it if the task œÑùúè\tau is most urgent and profitable in current block height. As such, for FL tasks with different difficulty levels, the relatively stable throughput of the blockchain system can be obtained.

Fig.¬†8 shows the throughput and the block latency of PF-PoFL in the distributed setting when the block size increases from 0.5 MB to 10 MB. It can be observed that our PF-PoFL system can efficiently handle hundreds of transactions per second and the block latency is below 47 seconds. As seen in Fig.¬†8, with the increase of block size, the block latency keeps increasing while the blockchain throughput first increases then decreases when the block size is over 8.5 MB. It can be explained as follows. On one hand, the higher block size indicates that more transactions are included within a block, resulting in a higher latency in transaction processing and block propagation. On the other hand, the relatively higher block size means that more transactions to be processed in a new block, which brings a higher TPS. However, the TPS cannot grow with the block size all the time. The reason is when the block size is too large (i.e., over 8.5 MB), the time to verify and broadcast the block can be extended, so that the distributed blockchain cannot be synchronized in time.

Table¬†II shows the time cost of executing model ranking contract in PF-PoFL under the distributed setting. The execution time of model ranking contract mainly consists of two parts: the contract running time (to produce local model ranking result) and the time to reach agreement on the final model ranking result (to be committed on blockchain). Note that in Algorithm 1, each validator can process multiple FL model transactions (including model downloading and evaluation) in parallel to reduce the contract running time. As seen in Table¬†II, the average contract running time of validators is 4.952 seconds and the time to reach agreement is 16.583 seconds, leading to a overall latency of about 21.1 seconds.

Table¬†III compares the time cost of model operations for pools and validators in PoFL and PF-PoFL under both local and distributed settings. As seen in Table¬†III, PoFL involves huge computation cost in model evaluation process (i.e., calculating model performance), especially for pools due to the expensive HE operations. Compared with the PoFL scheme, our PF-PoFL adds the Gaussian noise according to Eqs. (7) and (8) to ensure UDP for miners, and the time cost for pools in this process can be negligible. For model ranking and verification operations performed by validators, PoFL only needs to determine the best model. It indicates that if the model with the best performance is verified as true, there is no need to verify other models. In our PF-PoFL, each validator needs to test and sort all relevant models to determine the financial rewards and credit incentives in the block rewarding contract, causing a longer running time (e.g., 172 microseconds for model ranking and 2.927 seconds for model verification in setting 2) than that in the PoFL (e.g., 51 microseconds for model ranking and 1.296 seconds for model verification in setting 2). Besides, Table¬†III shows that the total consensus time for reaching agreement among validators on a new block is about 9.4 seconds in our PF-PoFL in setting 1 (resp. 21.3 seconds in setting 2), which is faster than that in the PoFL, i.e., 12.2 seconds in setting 1 (resp. 39.8 seconds in setting 2). The reasons are as follows. On one hand, the block proposal in PoFL involves huge storage space for encrypted model parameters in HE and 2PC, resulting in a higher block propagation latency. On the other hand, our credit-based Algorand BA protocol can employ more honest miners in the validator committee and incentivize miners to act legitimately and actively, thereby reducing the voting stages and the delay in reaching an unambiguous agreement.

VI-C Federated Mining with UDP

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the federated mining process with UDP on MNIST and CIFAR-10, in comparison with the baseline scheme, by changing the number of miners and values of privacy parameters. In the baseline scheme, the curator in a pool directly delivers the raw global update (instead of the perturbed version) to all miners. Fig.¬†9 illustrates the relationship between average EMD Œû¬Øjsubscript¬ØŒûùëó\overline{\Xi}_{j} and relative accuracy loss ‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œû¬Øj)‚Ñ∞subscript¬ØŒûùëó\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j}) in Eq. (25) on CIFAR-10 dataset under non-IID settings. As seen in Fig.¬†9, the relative accuracy loss first grows slowly and tends to increase fast when Œû¬Øj>1.2subscript¬ØŒûùëó1.2\overline{\Xi}_{j}>1.2. Besides, when Œû¬Øj=0subscript¬ØŒûùëó0\overline{\Xi}_{j}=0, it corresponds to the IID case and we have ‚Ñ∞‚Äã(Œû¬Øj)=1‚Ñ∞subscript¬ØŒûùëó1\mathcal{E}(\overline{\Xi}_{j})=1. According to Eq. (22), a higher EMD indicates a higher non-IID degree, and thereby a larger drop on test accuracy.

Figs.¬†10 and 11 show the evolution of test accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different privacy parameters in our UDP noise-adding mechanism, respectively, compared with baseline schemes. In this simulation, the number of participating miners is fixed as 100. As seen in Figs.¬†10 and 11, the test accuracy of the trained model via federated mining with œÉ=3ùúé3\sigma=3 UDP noise is very close to the baseline under non-IID, while the accuracies of the trained model with œÉ=14ùúé14\sigma=14 and œÉ=24ùúé24\sigma=24 are decreased to a certain degree. It is because a higher œÉùúé\sigma implies a higher privacy preservation level, causing larger perturbations to be added to the global model update in Eq. (8) which eventually deteriorates the model accuracy. Moreover, compared with the IID case, the existence of non-IID results in an accuracy drop to the baseline.

Figs.¬†12 and 13 show the evolution of test accuracy on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different pool sizes (i.e., number of miners in a pool), respectively. In this simulation, we set œÉ=3ùúé3\sigma=3. From Figs.¬†12 and 13, we can observe that with a larger pool size, the performance of the trained model is improving in terms of both accuracy and stability. The reason is that given the fixed sample ratio, when the number of participating miners in a pool increases, the impact of the added UDP noise to the global update in Eq. (8) can be reduced, resulting in the higher accuracy and stability in training FL models.

VI-D Federation Formation Game

In this subsection, we evaluate the performance of the proposed federation formation game in comparison with the exhaustive optimal scheme, the non-cooperative scheme, and the PoFL scheme [15]. In the exhaustive optimal scheme, the optimal pool structure among miners is derived via the exhaustive searching method in a centralized manner. In the non-cooperative scheme, each miner behaves uncooperatively and applies the solo-mining strategy in completing FL tasks. In PoFL scheme [15], all miners utilize the off-the-shelf fixed pooled-mining structure in PoW-based blockchains for federated mining. Here, the total number of miners is set as N=100ùëÅ100N=100, where miners perform federated mining on CIFAR-10 using the ResNet18 model under the setting 1.

Fig.¬†14 compares the social welfare WùëäW defined in formula (V-A) in four schemes. As shown in Fig.¬†14, when the number of iterations grows, the social welfare of miner partition in the proposed FFG-TU game gradually converges to a stable value after around 7 iterations. Besides, the proposed FFG-TU game can yield a near-optimal performance, as its performance gap to the exhaustive optimal solution does not exceed 2.1% when h‚â•7‚Ñé7h\geq 7. In addition, as seen in Fig.¬†14, the stable social welfare in our FFG-TU game is greater than that in the non-cooperative scheme and the PoFL scheme, and it brings up to about 67% improvement to the non-cooperative scheme and about 17.6% improvement to the PoFL scheme when h=10‚Ñé10h=10. The reason is that in the non-cooperative scheme, all miners work alone and each of them forms a singleton in conducting FL tasks, resulting in the lowest social welfare. Besides, as different miners generally have distinct training samples and non-IID degrees under heterogenous FL tasks, the fixed mining pool structure in the PoFL scheme cannot adapt to the varying federated mining environment, resulting in relatively lower social welfare.

Fig.¬†15 further inspects the evolution of partition structure among miners over time in terms of the number of pools and the number of switch operations. As seen in Figs.¬†14 and 15, the switch operations at each iteration can improve the social welfare for miners, which accords with Lemma¬†1. Moreover, as observed in Fig.¬†15, the proposed pool formation algorithm converges to a final disjoint partition structure after 7 iterations and achieves Nash-stability, which accords with Theorems¬†3 and 4. Besides, Fig.¬†15 shows that, the number of switch operations |‚àë(h)|superscript‚Ñé|\sum^{(h)}| at each iteration h‚Ñéh satisfies |‚àë(h)|‚â§|‚Ñë(h)|+1superscript‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé1|\sum^{(h)}|\leq|\Im^{(h)}|+1, where |‚Ñë(h)|superscript‚Ñé|\Im^{(h)}| is the number of pools in current partition ‚Ñë(h)superscript‚Ñé\Im^{(h)}. The reason is that, according to the switch rule and admission rule in Definitions¬†7 and 8, each miner can either switch to another pool or form a singleton if it decides to leave the current pool, while each pool only admits the optimal miner greedily at each iteration.

According to the aforementioned results, our PF-PoFL can effectively recycle energy for efficient federated mining and attain stable throughput of the blockchain system, low block latency in reaching consensus, desirable model performance with UDP guarantees, and optimized federated structure with high social welfare.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed a novel energy-recycling consensus mechanism named PF-PoFL, where the wasted energy in solving cryptographic puzzles in PoW is reinvested to FL. To implement PF-PoFL in a fully decentralized manner, we utilize the blockchain to host the unfinished tasks, perform model ranking, and enforce financial settlement by devising a novel block structure, a model ranking contract, and a block rewarding contract. PF-PoFL also incorporates credit-based incentives to motivate miners' honest participation and improve consensus efficiency. Furthermore, a user-level privacy-preserving model training algorithm is designed to offer rigorous privacy protection for miners in each pool. In addition, based on the federation formation game, we present an optimized pool formulation algorithm, where miners with diverse characteristics (i.e., training samples, non-IID degree, and network delay) in heterogenous FL tasks can self-organize into a disjoint Nash-stable partition. Simulation results have validated the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed PF-PoFL mechanism. For the future work, we will further investigate the optimized PF-PoFL consensus mechanism with optimal FL task rewarding, task difficulty adjustment function, and non-reusability guarantees.
